data.origin: Old English freond, of Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: People with whom one has a bond of mutual affection.
definitions.example: They have been best friends since childhood.

data.origin: Late Middle English from Latin tutor ‘a watcher, guardian’.

definitions.definition: A private teacher, typically one who teaches a single student or a small group.
definitions.example: She hired a math tutor for extra help.

definitions.definition: To act as a tutor to someone; to teach.

data.origin: Old English hamor, of Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: A tool with a heavy metal head mounted at right angles at the end of a handle.
definitions.example: He used a hammer to drive the nail into the wall.

definitions.definition: To hit or beat something with a hammer or similar object.
definitions.example: She hammered the metal into shape.

definitions.definition: The action of giving someone support, confidence, or hope.
definitions.example: Your kind words gave me the encouragement I needed.

data.origin: Mid 16th century, from Greek katastrophē ‘overturning, sudden turn’.

definitions.definition: An event causing great and often sudden damage or suffering.
definitions.example: The earthquake was a complete catastrophe for the region.

definitions.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning.
definitions.example: His reply was ambiguous and left us wondering.

data.origin: Mid 16th century, from Latin coalescere ‘grow together’.

definitions.definition: To come together to form one mass or whole.
definitions.example: The streams coalesce into a single river.

data.origin: Late 18th century, from French, from Latin amator ‘lover’.

definitions.definition: A person who engages in a pursuit on an unpaid basis.

data.origin: Middle English, via Old French and ecclesiastical Latin from Greek hierarkhia.

definitions.definition: A system in which members are ranked according to status or authority.
definitions.example: The company had a strict hierarchy of command.

definitions.definition: Having the same or nearly the same meaning as another word or phrase.
definitions.example: In this context, ‘happy’ is synonymous with ‘joyful’.
